text: It's Advertising Week Social Club. I'm Zanger in Portland, New Bear in Lexington, Kentucky. We are wrapping up today. Question four. What is the question again? Today's closing question is what do you think the future holds for music and advertising? Is it bright, dim, something else? And the hashtag as always is AWSCchat. I would be in the it can be bright category. I think it's I think it's fun. It always involves perspective for me. People get so upset when something becomes popular and it's not necessarily good or when something that is wonderfully brilliant doesn't become popular. And then upon reflection later, after it does become popular or still doesn't succeed. You know, my friends love to tease me because I love 90s R&B. You put me on a desert island with some boys to men. I'd be all right. Right. But not everybody does. Right. And. Not everybody likes the way that music and advertising is. We're not everybody's a fan of YouTube. Not everybody's a fan of health, social media. Right. And the intersection of everything. What we just talked to the good friend, a new AWSC family member from Brazil about is how different cultures are. Right. How about how many differences there are within the same culture? So I just I always want to challenge when we've got so many different things coming in right now. It's blinding. It's brilliant. It's going to be amazing. And then there's other people who say music sucks. And the perspective in the moment is almost impossible. Well, and again, this is a this is a bit of a polarizing topic. It's music is one of the things in our lives, not just in our work lives, but in our lives. That is probably one of the most intimate things that you can share. One of the most intimate things you can talk about. People care deeply about. About music and where it shows up and how it shows up and whatever. You know, I I look I think that it's going to be very bright if it is a tool that is used properly. So Whit Thompson says, I hope we see the end of the misappropriation of songs for poorly matched products. I think that there that's that is a that is a very, very, very good point. And I think that I think the brands and agencies are. Getting better at it. And I think they're I think they're good at it now. But I think that there's there's room to really grow. And I think that it really depends on, you know, really solid music director at an agency. That's just that's just sticking to their guns or a label or an artist that that can articulate why a certain song should be licensed for a certain product. I think that there's I think that there's this growing level of sophistication. And I think that the consumer is incredibly savvy. And. They're not easily hoodwinked. And I think that they see, well, that doesn't match. And well, there's there's so much more information. You can Google lyrics to a song in five seconds and learn very quickly that maybe some of these other folks should be tied to something that's mom and pop shop. Cute. Right. As a fan of alt rock slash indie. I love to see my favorite bands kick top 40. But once in a while. And this goes all the way back to the very first question that we asked today about the idea of of selling well or selling out, selling out or selling well. Right. Because when you take some underground alt rock indie band and they become super popular because of something that they do specifically for a pop culture. I think if you're an artist and having been in radio for a while and seeing, you know, seeing artists who really genuinely want to, you know, really want to really want to want things to work for them. And I remember I remember Busta Rhymes said this. Listen, I remember Busta Rhymes said this once. He was he was doing an interview at the station that I was at. And he somebody called in and said. What advice do you have for young up and coming artists? And he said, get the best deal that you can get. Just make sure that you are getting the best deal that you can get. I might be a long haired hippie freak, but I am a big fan of people doing what they love and hopefully being compensated accordingly for it, especially for artists, because it is incredibly, incredibly challenging. It is unbeatable. It is unbelievably competitive. And if you have an opportunity to spread the word about just your talent in the advertising sphere, I say go for it. But again, the other side of that is you got to make sure it's a perfect match. Yeah. And I mean, let's talk about for every artist who's ever accused Russell Simmons of stealing from him. And let's be honest, if you look at some of the bad deals that people sign to get out of the hood and make some money and make a name for themselves, there was some crazy stuff that happened. But then on the flip side of that, in a completely different genre, you look at someone like Green River. It took them 12 years to make it. They finally get their big contract deal. They're doing cross country or international tours. They just left the label. They're going to their next album is all on them. And the world, just like social media, just like smartphones, just like mobile technology and everything that goes with it. The world of music in and of itself is a dramatically different landscape than it has ever been. Right. Right. It was a huge deal. Ray Charles was the one who. You know, I'm going to do it my way. This one, I'm going to get paid. I get all the everything's mine. And everyone, the big the big shock and awe of the whole thing was Sinatra didn't even get that kind of a deal. Right. Right. And today they the bands have much more control. It makes you wonder how much someone like we talk about stained. We touched on Green Day for me is the biggest one in terms of change. And also the reaction caused by that change. How much would a band like Green Day have felt? Like they had to change, shift, morph and do some things if they came out today. Good point. All right. We're going to wrap it up. We went a little bit long today, but thank you very much. A very vibrant conversation. As always, we can't thank you enough for your contributions. You guys are amazing. And we will see you next week on the AWSC chat.
